did.unittitle: Republican Party (Mich.) State Central Committee Records 1958-1979 1962-1978
did.physloc: Portions of the collection are located offsite; two days notice required for retrieval.
did.abstract: Office files and papers of state chairpersons William F. McLaughlin, Arthur Elliott and Elly Peterson, executive director Jerry Roe, public relations director Hugh Humphrey, and Joseph Hunting, executive director of the Republican State Finance Committee. The principal series in this record group include: Annual reports/Executive Committee meetings; Chairperson's files; Staff/Departments; Topical Files; Campaign Files; Convention Files; Miscellaneous; Sound Recordings; and Photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated by the Republican State Central Committee (donor no. 6293) in 1979 and by state chairman William McLaughlin (donor no. 6270) also in 1979. A small group of records was donated by executive director Jerry Roe (donor no. 5238) in 1979.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

The collection contains audio tapes from which digital copies have been made. Source tapes are for staff use only. Audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.

userestrict.p: The SCC has transferred its copyright to the regents of the University of Michigan. William McLaughlin has not made a transfer of copyright.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Republican Party (Mich.). State Central Committee, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

altformavail.p: Digitization: The Library has undertaken the digitization of a number of sound recordings within this collection. The resulting audio files are available for playback only in the Bentley Library Reading Room. Links to item images and additional information are available within this finding aid. Original sound recordings are only available for staff use.

bioghist.p: The exact date when the Republican State Central Committee was organized is not clear but it was probably very soon after the establishment of the party in 1854. In the library, there is a pamphlet published around 1856 with the citation "printed by the Michigan Republican Committee." What the responsibilities of this committee were is not certain, but the name obviously implies some degree of party organization and function such as might have been performed by the agency known in 1883, when its membership was first listed in the Michigan Manual, as the state central committee.

For the period represented by the bulk of these records (approximately from the mid-1950s to 1979), the party distinguished between the State Central Committee and State Central. The committee is the policy arm of the party which meets for two day meetings five times a year. State Central, on the other hand, is the day-to-day professional organization of the state Republican party. Functioning as a service organization, State Central acts as liaison on party affairs in the state's congressional districts, in each county, and at the city and township level. The kinds of work performed by State Central depends upon the funds available. Staff includes a state chairman, an executive director, field representatives, and clerical support.

Specific responsibilities of State Central and the state chairman include running state conventions and planning the state party's participation in the national convention; working with and providing training for Republican candidates on the state, district, and county levels; receiving communications from and with the Republican National Committee and the national administration (when a Republican is in the White House); cooperating with the governor or the state legislature on special issues (such as congressional redistricting, legislative apportionment, appointments to state boards and commissions, etc.); developing campaign material for certain statewide offices; finding and encouraging qualified people to run for Congress and for the state legislature; and otherwise acting as the voice of the Republican Party at countless conferences, seminars, rallys, and workshops.

The state Republican Party in the period represented by these records underwent a process of rejuvenation. From 1949 to 1962, Democrats were in the governor's office. The election of 1962 saw the emergence of automobile executive George Romney as a powerful vote-getter and someone who clearly had ambitions for national office. Other Republicans on the scene were his successor William Milliken and, of course, the man who became Michigan's only president Gerald R. Ford. Significant campaigns in the period of this record group include the senatorial campaigns of Elly Peterson and Lenore Romney in 1964 and 1970 respectively, George Romney and William Milliken campaigns for governor, and Gerald Ford's campaign for reelection to the presidency in 1976.

arrangement.p:
The Republican Party State Central Committee record group has been divided into the following series:
Annual Reports/Executive Committee Meetings - Box 1
Chairman's Files - Box 1-18
Staff/Departments - Box 19-39
Topical Files - Box 39-50
Campaigns - Box 50-62
Conventions - Box 62-66
Miscellaneous - Box 66-68
Sound Recordings - Box 69-70
Photographs. - Box 71

scopecontent.p: The records of the Michigan Republican State Central Committee (hereafter SCC) consist of files generated over a twenty-year period by the three chairpersons, William F. McLaughlin, Arthur Elliott and Elly Peterson, who served in this period and by different staff members and departments within the party organization including executive director Jerry Roe, public relations director Hugh Humphrey, and Joseph Hunting, executive director of the Republican State Finance Committee. Although an attempt was made to maintain and otherwise arrange the files into series according to the name of the individual or department within the party that created the record, this was not always possible with the papers of the SCC. Thus some of the larger series within the collection, notably Topical Files and Campaign Files, have been drawn from different sources when that source of origin was not apparent or the files contained materials from two or more individuals

The record group begins with a series of Annual Reports/Executive Committee Meetings files. The Annual Reports are published summaries of activities but only two reports have been found. The bylaws are important for stating something about the organization and function of the state central committee. Of most value are the files of executive committee meeting files. Ranging in date from 1965 to 1978, the files detail the specific actions and development of programs within the party.

odd.p: (material for some years is sparse)

scopecontent.p: The Chairman's Files are arranged by name of the chairs who served from 1963 to 1979: Arthur Elliott, Elly Peterson, and William McLaughlin. The largest grouping of files are for William McLaughlin who was elected to the office in 1969. The smallest set of files are for Arthur Elliott and then Elly Peterson. Additional Elly Peterson files from the period when she was SCC chair will be found in her collection of personal papers also on file at the library. Kinds of materials within these three subseries include correspondence, speeches and subject files. The correspondence consists of communications with state, county, and district Republican leaders with words of encouragement and concern. The largest subseries is for William McLaughlin which includes files of communication with the chair of the Republican National Committee, and records from McLaughlin's work with the Michigan Legislative Apportionment Commission in 1971-1972.

did.unittitle: Election of WM as SCC chair 1969, 1973, 1975

scopecontent.p: Staff Files/Department Files document the ongoing operations and work of the party. Larger subseries here will detail the work of executive director Jerry Roe, the Republican State Finance Committee, and those staff and departments concerned with research and the press. Within the research subseries is an extensive People file containing biographical and campaign material about Republican candidates for office, information about Democratic opposition candidates, and other Republican leaders. A subseries that documents the party's work among targeted voting blocs is "Other Republican Organizations." Here will be found publications, correspondence, memoranda, and other documents concerning the party's work with youth, women, nationality groups, African Americans, and veterans.

scopecontent.p: The Topical Files is a large series, approximately 11 linear feet in size, and drawn from different and miscellaneous sources. The origin of the materials is not clear though some of it undoubtedly could be associated with the research subseries described Staff Files/Department Files, or with the subject files maintained by the chair of the SCC. Because of this uncertainty, the files were drawn together and alphabetized. Significant portions of this series detail Republican party meetings and conferences.

scopecontent.p: Although much of the record group pertains in some way to election campaigns, the series Campaigns is a convenient source of information about the candidates and issues in the state and national elections in the period of 1962 to 1978. The series includes much campaign material and memoranda about issues and strategy.

odd.p: (includes files from Lenore Romney's 1970 campaign for the U.S. Senate)

scopecontent.p: The Convention series has files on the administration, platform, and procedures of the state conventions and on the participation of the state delegation to the Republican National Convention.

odd.p: (continued)

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous series includes files of background information compiled on various individuals prior to their appointment to various state boards and commissions. Similar files will be found in the papers of individual Michigan governors also housed at the library.
Sound recordings consists of reel-to-reel tapes of Republican events such as state conventions.

accessrestrict.p: [Digitized audio files are only available in the Bentley Historical Library reading room on designated Bentley Library computers.]

scopecontent.p: Photographs in the SCC records are primarily portraits of candidates for state office, although there are some campaign views and a Detroit polling place where there was a question of voter fraud.
